questions.text: A woman would get anxious, mood swings with occasional sleep disturbance and weeping episodes after birth of child and got referred from Obstetrics dept after 5 days post delivery. What is most probable diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A patient who has taken lithium for some months discontinues it and says ‘the ocean needs a sail as rat needs a tail, so write your exam and don’t fail, results will be out in a mail’. Which of the following symptoms is he exhibiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clang associations
• Sail-tail-fail-mail (rhyming is observed which is characteristic of clang associations)
• Not flight of ideas, because no specific one word connection
• Not tangentiality, because no evidence of losing the track
• Not Neologisms, because no new words used

questions.text: A patient presented to the psychiatry OPD. On being asked what's your name', patient repeated the same question. This phenomenon is called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
• Repeating examiners words is echolalia

questions.text: What is the minimum duration of symptoms required to diagnose schizophrenia as per ICD-11?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1 month
• As per ICD-11, minimum duration = 1 month
• As per DSM-5, minimum duration = 6 months

choices.text: Loss of interest in pleasurable activities

questions.text: Which of the following is a key feature of depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Low mood is key symptom of depressio

choices.text: History of Mood symptoms at the time of Diagnosis

questions.text: A 30year old Female developed paranoid Schizophrenia and is on treatment. Her father would like to know the prognosis of this patient. Which of the following factors indicate a poor prognostic factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Insidious in onset
(Ref: Kaplan Synopsis of Psychiatry 11th edn)
Features Weighting Toward Good to Poor Prognosis in Schizophrenia

questions.text: Which type of personality traits are seen in relatives of patients with schizophrenia?(*)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Schizotypal
(Ref : Kaplan synopsis pg 303)
Schizophrenia and schizophrenia-related disorders (e.g., schizotypal personality disorder) occur at an increased rate among the biological relatives of patients with schizophrenia.

questions.text: Inappropriate affect is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Schizophrenia
Bipolar disorder has appropriate affect (congruent to mood/emotional state)
Schizophrenia has inappropriate affect (not matching to inner emotional state)

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as the strongest predictor of suicide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Feeling of hopelessness
Risk factors for suicide:
• Previous suicide attempt (most imp)
• Family history of suicide
• Male gender
• Family history of child abuse
• History of mental disorders, particularly clinical depression
• History of alcohol and substance abuse
• Feelings of hopelessness
• Impulsive or aggressive tendencies
• Cultural and religious beliefs (e.g., belief that suicide is noble resolution of a personal dilemma)
• Local epidemics of suicide
• Isolation, a feeling of being cut off from other people
• Living alone
• Barriers to accessing mental health treatment
• Loss (relational, social, work, or financial)
• Physical illness
• Easy access to lethal methods
• Unwillingness to seek help because of the stigma attached to mental health and substance abuse disorders or to suicidal thoughts

questions.text: Which of the following is schizophrenic first rank symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Made affect
Schizophrenic first rank symptoms are: (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)
1. Audible thoughts: Voices speaking out thoughts aloud or ‘ thought echo’.
2. Voices heard arguing: Two or more hallucinatory voices discussing the subject in third person.
3. Voices commenting on one’s action.
4. Thought withdrawal: Thoughts cease and subject experiences them as removed by an external force.
5. Thought insertion: Experience of thoughts imposed by some external force on person’s passive mind.
6. Thought diffusion or broadcasting: Experience of thoughts escaping the confines of self and as being experienced by others around.
7. ‘ Made’ feelings or affect.
8. ‘Made’ impulses.
9. ‘Made’ volition or acts: In ‘made’ affect, impulses and volitions, the person experiences feelings, impulses or acts which are imposed by some external force. In ‘made’ volition, for example, one’s own acts are experienced as being under the control of some external force.
10. Somatic passivity: Bodily sensations, especially sensory symptoms, are experienced as imposed on body by some external force.
11. Delusional perception: Normal perception has a private and illogical meaning.

questions.text: Fixation of “Dependent personality disorder” is at which stage of psychosexual development :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Oral
(Ref : Kaplan Psychiatry Pg 743)
Sigmund Freud suggested that personality traits are related to a fixation at one psychosexual stage of development. For example, those with an oral character are passive and dependent because they are fixated at the oral stage, when the dependence on others for food is prominent. Those with an anal character are stubborn, parsimonious, and highly conscientious because of struggles over toilet training during the anal period.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a negative symptom in Schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Automatism (Ref: Kaplan Synopsis of Psychiatry 11th edn)

Alogia, Affective flattening and Anhedonia are negative symptoms of schizophrenia. Automatism is seen in seizures

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, used in alcohol dependence, acts on NMDA receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ref: Kaplan Synopsis of Psychiatry 11th edn)
Acamprosate is NMDA receptor antagonist, used in alcohol deaddiction

questions.text: Which of the following drugs have no physical dependence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

LSD

questions.text: A 60-years-old man whose wife died 3 months back now starts to believe that his intestines have rotten away and that he is responsible for the death of his wife and should be sent to prison. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Psychotic depression
Psychotic depression. The symptoms in this question are suggestive of nihilistic delusions (intestine are rotting away) and pathological guilt (belief that patient is responsible for death). Both these symptoms are usually seen in patients with severe depression. The death of wife could have acted as the stressor that resulted in the development of severe depressive episode with psychotic symptoms (or psychotic depression).

questions.text: Savant syndrome is most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Autism
Savant syndrome is a rare, but extraordinary, condition in which persons with serious mental disabilities, including autistic disorder, have some ‘island of genius’ which stands in marked, incongruous contrast to overall handicap. As many as one in 10 persons with autistic disorder have such remarkable abilities in varying degrees, although savant syndrome occurs in other developmental disabilities or in other types of central nervous system injury or disease as well.

questions.text: A 42 year old male with a past history of a manic episode presents with an illness of 1 month duration characterized by depressed mood, anhedonia and profound psychomotor retardation. The most appropriate management strategy is prescribing a combination of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Antidepressants and mood stabilizers.
(This is a case of bipolar depression where you need to give both antidepressant and as well as mood stabilizer. If you give alone antidepressant, than he may go to manic phase)

questions.text: Antidepressant used in smoking cessation? (*)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bupropion

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was seen by a school counselor after the teachers complained of his behavior in school. He frequently becomes angry towards others and loses his temper in class. His parents report that at home, he refuses to comply with house rules, often stays up later than he is supposed to, and frequently talks back to them. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Oppositional defiant disorder
Children with oppositional defiant disorder usually have problems with authority figures such as parents and teachers. Unlike children with conduct disorder, they do not break rules of society and do not commit crimes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was recently seen by her primary care physician due to complaints of depressed mood, lack of pleasure, sleep problems, decreased appetite and weight, decreased energy, and problems with concentration. She states that these symptoms started when she was fired from her job about 4 weeks ago, and that since then, she has been unable to function. What is the most indicated treatment at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paroxetine
She has a diagnosis of major depression and the first line treatment is the use of an SSRI medication because of a better side-effect profile compared to the other therapies. Bupropion, would be useful but not the first choice. Alprazolam is simply a benzodiazepine and acts as an anxiolytic, not an antidepressant. Electroconvulsive therapy might be useful if initial therapy did not work or the depression was far more severe and was associated with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought to the office by his daughter after she became concerned about him. He has been hopeless and helpless since his wife died 3 months ago. His daughter is worried about his isolative behavior and lack of appetite. He has lost over 30 pounds. He does not seem interested in getting better and believes he should have died with his wife. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Major Depression
Although it has been less than 6 months since his wife died, his symptoms are severe enough to warrant a diagnosis of major depression. He has no interest in things, has lost weight, feels hopeless and helpless, and believes he should have died as well. He needs to be treated with antidepressants, and we must ensure that he is not suicidal since he is at high risk.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was referred to a psychiatrist by his physician because he is "too shy." He has problems going to parties, feels anxious about getting close to others, and stays at home in fear that others would laugh at him. When confronted by others, he develops severe anxiety as well as hyperventilation and increased sweating. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Social Anxiety
Social anxiety is characterized by fear of embarrassment in social situations. These patients have problems going out in fear that others will laugh at them.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has complained of palpitations, dizziness, and increased sweating for at least 8 months. She has visited numerous physicians and none have been helpful. Her husband is concerned because she cannot relax and worries about everything. She worries about her parents' health even though they are healthy. She worries about her finances, although her husband assures her they are financially secure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Generalised Anxiety Disorder
The main feature of generalized anxiety disorder is the chronic worrying about things that do not merit concern. It is also accompanied by other symptoms of anxiety, as well as sleep and concentration problems.

questions.text: Most common extrapyramidal side effect? (*)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Akathisia 
Akathisia > Pseduoparkinsonism
Akathisia is a peculiar state of somatic restlessness manifesting both subjectively and objectively in about 25%-50% patients on antipsychotics. (Ref : IPS, Maudsley guidelines)

questions.text: Most common side effect of clozapine? (*)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sedation
Sedation > Silaorrhoea

questions.text: Weight gain due to antipsychotics is due to its action on which receptors? (*)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5HT2c

questions.text: Morbid jealousy is caused by excessive use of? (*)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alcohol (Latest exam Q)
Marked jealousy (usually termed pathological or morbid jealousy) is thus a symptom of many disorders including schizophrenia (in which female patients more commonly display this feature), epilepsy, mood disorders, drug abuse, and alcoholism for which treatment is directed at the primary disorder. (Ref : Pg 508, Kaplan textbook)

questions.text: Which SSRI will cause least problem on abrupt withdrawal of the drug? (***)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Fluoxetine
(Ref : Kaplan Psychiatry Pg 1014)
"The abrupt discontinuance of SSRI use, especially one with a shorter half-life (e.g., paroxetine or fluvoxamine), has been associated with a withdrawal syndrome that can include dizziness, weakness, nausea, headache, rebound depression, anxiety, insomnia, poor concentration, upper respiratory symptoms, paresthesias, and migraine-like symptoms. Fluoxetine is the SSRI least likely to be associated with this syndrome, because the half-life of its metabolite is more than 1 week and it effectively tapers itself."

questions.text: Shortest phase of sexual cycle? (*)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Orgasm 
(Ref : Kaplan Psychiatry Pg 568)
Orgasmic phase lasts for 3-15 seconds in both males and females.
Resolution phase is 10-15 minutes.
Excitement Phase Lasts several minutes to several hours.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents at the local clinic complaining of abdominal cramps, sweating, runny nose, vomiting, and muscle aches. Examination shows that his pulse is rapid and pupils are dilated. He states that he "feels just awful" and that he has had these symptoms for about 24 hours. The most likely pharmacologic treatment would be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clonidine
The man is suffering from opiate withdrawal. The drug on the list to treat the withdrawal is clonidine.

questions.text: A middle aged man suddenly becomes detached, and starts writing poems and stories, although it couldn’t be understood by anyone because of language and context was also not rational. Most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Schizophrenia
The clinical sign described is “Neologism” which is most likely seen in schizophrenia.

questions.text: Which of the following antipsychotic has anti-suicidal role? (**)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Clozapine
Lithium and Clozapine have anti-suicidal properties. (CLOZAPINE: VIP DRUG)

questions.text: Pleasure neurotransmitter of human mind?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dopamine
Decreased dopamine has more been implicated to cause anhedonia than decreased serotonin.

questions.text: Bad trip is seen with which of the following drugs:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

LSD > B. Cannabis
Although it is seen in both, better is LSD.
Kaplan pg 432 “The most common adverse effect of LSD and related substances is a “bad trip”, an experience resembling the acute panic reaction to cannabis but sometimes more severe; a bad trip can occasionally produce true psychotic symptoms. The bad trip generally ends when the immediate effects of the hallucinogen wear off, but its course is variable.”

questions.text: A 26-years-old woman with panic disorder notes that during the middle of one of her attacks she feels as if she is disconnected from her   body, and feels as if she is floating above it. Which of the following terms best describes this symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Depersonalization
Feelings “as if” detached from the body suggests depersonalization.

questions.text: A young man gets sudden and irresistible urge to carry out an act.  This is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
• Sudden irresistible urge to carry out an act is impulse

questions.text: A 65 year old man with a history of chronic alcohol use  presents to his primary care clinic. Now he is admitted with features  of vision loss, confusion and unsteady gait. He cannot recall about  the recent events. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for his  symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
• History is suggestive of alcohol related “Wernicke’s Korsakoff syndrome” that is due to deficiency of thiamine

questions.text: A female patient of bipolar disorder is on lithium for last 1 year.  Which of the following side effects is least likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
• Tardive dyskinesia is extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic

questions.text: Which of the following side effects is more commonly seen with oxcarbazepine as compared to that of carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hyponatremia
While dermatological side effects are notably more in carbamazepine as compared with oxcarbazepine, hyponatremia is more with oxcarbazepine

questions.text: A young man is often the object of his friends’ jokes because he drops to the floor whenever he is having a good laugh. Which of the following is this man most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Narcolepsy
Loss of tone on emotional events is cataplexy, which is seen in narcolepsy. Remember,
Catalepsy: catatonia; cataplexy: narcolepsy
